introduction.p: Up to this point, we have used the Gaussian elimination algorithm to find solutions to linear systems. We now investigate another way to find solutions to the equation A\xvec=\bvec when the matrix A has the same number of rows and columns. To get started, let's look at some familiar examples.

statement.p: Explain how you would solve the equation 3x = 5 using multiplication rather than division.

solution.p:
Dividing by 3 is the same as multiplying by \frac13, the multiplicative inverse \frac13 of 3. We have
\begin{array}{rl} \frac13(3x) \amp = \dfrac13 5 \\ \left(\frac13 3\right)x\amp = \dfrac53 \\ 1x \amp = \dfrac 53 \\ x \amp = \dfrac53\text{.} \\ \end{array}

statement.p: Find the 2\times2 matrix A that rotates vectors counterclockwise by 90^\circ.
Find the 2\times2 matrix B that rotates vectors clockwise by 90^\circ.
What do you expect the product AB to be? Explain the reasoning behind your expectation and then compute AB to verify it.

solution.p: We should expect that AB=I since the effect of rotating by 90^\circ clockwise followed by rotating 90^\circ counterclockwise is to leave a vector unchanged. We can verify this by performing the matrix multiplication.

statement.p: Solve the equation A\xvec = \twovec{3}{-2} using Gaussian elimination.

solution.p:
We have
\left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 0 \amp -1 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right]
so the solution is \xvec=\twovec{-2}{-3}.

statement.p: Explain why your solution may also be found by computing \xvec = B\twovec{3}{-2}.

solution.p:
The equation A\xvec=\twovec{3}{-2} is asking us to find the vector that becomes \twovec{3}{-2} after being rotated by 90^\circ. If we rotate \twovec{3}{-2} by 90^\circ in the opposite direction, it will have this property. That is, if \xvec = B\twovec{-2}{-3}, then
A\xvec = A(B\xvec) = (AB)\twovec{3}{-2} = I\twovec{3}{-2} = \twovec{3}{-2}.

statement.p: I feel confident with the material in this activity.
What would you need to know to feel more confident about this material?

subsection.title: Invertible matrices

statement.p: A test question to see if a playground version is working properly.

subsection.p: The preview activity began with a familiar type of equation, 3x = 5, and asked for a strategy to solve it. One possible response is to divide both sides by 3. Instead, let's rephrase this as multiplying by 3^{-1} = \frac 13, the multiplicative inverse of 3.

Now that we are interested in solving equations of the form A\xvec = \bvec, we might try to find a similar approach. Is there a matrix A^{-1} that plays the role of the multiplicative inverse of A? Of course, the real number 0 does not have a multiplicative inverse so we probably shouldn't expect every matrix to have a multiplicative inverse. We will see, however, that many do.

statement.p: An n\times n matrix A is called invertible if there is a matrix B such that AB = I_n, where I_n is the n\times n identity matrix. The matrix B is called the inverse of A and denoted A^{-1}.

subsection.p: matrix, square Notice that we only define invertibility for matrices that have the same number of rows and columns in which case we say that the matrix is square.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is the matrix that rotates two-dimensional vectors counterclockwise by 90^\circ and that B rotates vectors by -90^\circ. We have
A=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right],~~~ B=\left[\begin{array}{rr} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right].
We can check that
AB = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \\ -1 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} = I
which shows that A is invertible and that A^{-1}=B.
Notice that if we multiply the matrices in the opposite order, we find that BA=I, which says that B is also invertible and that B^{-1} = A. In other words, A and B are inverses of each other.

This activity demonstrates a procedure for finding the inverse of a matrix A.
Suppose that A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix} . To find an inverse B, we write its columns as B = \begin{bmatrix}\bvec_1 \amp \bvec_2 \end{bmatrix} and require that
\begin{aligned} AB \amp = I \\ \begin{bmatrix} A\bvec_1 \amp A\bvec_2 \end{bmatrix} \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}
In other words, we can find the columns of B by solving the equations
A\bvec_1 = \twovec10,~~~ A\bvec_2 = \twovec01.
Solve these equations to find \bvec_1 and \bvec_2. Then write the matrix B and verify that AB=I. This is enough for us to conclude that B is the inverse of A.
Find the product BA and explain why we now know that B is invertible and B^{-1}=A.
What happens when you try to find the inverse of C = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \amp 1 \\ 4 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix}?
We now develop a condition that must be satisfied by an invertible matrix. Suppose that A is an invertible n\times n matrix with inverse B and suppose that \bvec is any n-dimensional vector. Since AB=I, we have
A(B\bvec) = (AB)\bvec = I\bvec = \bvec.
This says that the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent and that \xvec=B\bvec is a solution.
Since we know that A\xvec = \bvec is consistent for any vector \bvec, what does this say about the span of the columns of A?
Since A is a square matrix, what does this say about the pivot positions of A? What is the reduced row echelon form of A?
In this activity, we have studied the matrices
A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix},~~~ C = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \amp 1 \\ 4 \amp -2 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Find the reduced row echelon form of each and explain how those forms enable us to conclude that one matrix is invertible and the other is not.

li.p: Solving the two equations for \bvec_1 and \bvec_2 gives B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp -3 \\ \end{bmatrix}. We can verify that, as we expect, AB=I.
We find that BA=I, which is the condition that tells us that B is invertible.
Seeking the first column of C^{-1}, we see that the equation C\xvec = \twovec10 is not consistent. This means that C is not invertible.
Since the equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent for every \bvec, we know that the span of the columns of A is \real^n.

Because the span of the columns of A is \real^n, there is a pivot position in every row. Since A is square, there is also a pivot position in every column. This means that the reduced row echelon form of A must be the identity matrix I_n.

We see that
A\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix},~~~ C\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -\frac12 \\ 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix},
which shows that A is invertible and C is not.

statement.p:
We can reformulate this procedure for finding the inverse of a matrix. For the sake of convenience, suppose that A is a 2\times2 invertible matrix with inverse B=\begin{bmatrix} \bvec_1 \amp \bvec_2 \end{bmatrix}. Rather than solving the equations
A\bvec_1 = \twovec10,~~~ A\bvec_2 = \twovec01
separately, we can solve them at the same time by augmenting A by both vectors \twovec10 and \twovec01 and finding the reduced row echelon form.

For example, if A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}, we form
\left[ \begin{array}{rr|rr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{rr|rr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ \end{array} \right].
This shows that the matrix B = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp 2 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} is the inverse of A.

In other words, beginning with A, we augment by the identify and find the reduced row echelon form to determine A^{-1}:
\left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp I \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} I \amp A^{-1} \\ \end{array} \right].

subsection.p:
In fact, this reformulation will always work. Suppose that A is an invertible n\times n matrix with inverse B. Suppose furthermore that \bvec is any n-dimensional vector and consider the equation A\xvec = \bvec. We know that x=B\bvec is a solution because
A(B\bvec) = (AB)\bvec = I\bvec = \bvec.

statement.p: If A is an invertible matrix with inverse B, then any equation A\xvec = \bvec is consistent and \xvec = B\bvec is a solution. In other words, the solution to A\xvec = \bvec is \xvec = A^{-1}\bvec.

subsection.p: Notice that this is similar to saying that the solution to 3x=5 is x = \frac13\cdot 5, as we saw in the preview activity.

Now since A\xvec=\bvec is consistent for every vector \bvec, the columns of A must span \real^n so there is a pivot position in every row. Since A is also square, this means that the reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix.

statement.p:
The matrix A is invertible if and only if the reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix: A\sim I. In addition, we can find the inverse by augmenting A by the identity and finding the reduced row echelon form:
\left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp I \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} I \amp A^{-1} \\ \end{array} \right].

subsection.p: You may have noticed that says that the solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is \xvec = A^{-1}\bvec. Indeed, we know that this equation has a unique solution because A has a pivot position in every column.

It is important to remember that the product of two matrices depends on the order in which they are multiplied. That is, if C and D are matrices, then it sometimes happens that CD \neq DC. However, something fortunate happens when we consider invertibility. It turns out that if A is an n\times n matrix and that AB=I, then it is also true that BA=I. We have verified this in a few examples so far, and explains why it always happens. This leads to the following proposition.

statement.p:
If A is a n\times n invertible matrix with inverse B, then BA=I, which tells us that B is invertible with inverse A. In other words,
(A^{-1})^{-1} = A.

subsection.title: Solving equations with an inverse
subsection.p:
If A is an invertible matrix, then
shows us how to use A^{-1} to solve equations involving A. In particular, the solution to A\xvec = \bvec is \xvec = A^{-1}\bvec.

statement.p:
We'll begin by considering the square matrix
A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Describe the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \threevec343 by augmenting A and finding the reduced row echelon form.
Using , explain why A is invertible and find its inverse.
Now use the inverse to solve the equation A\xvec = \threevec343 and verify that your result agrees with what you found in part a.
If you have defined a matrix B in Sage, you can find it's inverse as B.inverse() or B^-1. Use Sage to find the inverse of the matrix
B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp -2 \amp -1 \\ -1 \amp 5 \amp 6 \\ 5 \amp -4 \amp 6 \\ \end{array}\right]
and use it to solve the equation B\xvec = \threevec83{36}.
If A and B are the two matrices defined in this activity, find their product AB and verify that it is invertible.
Compute the products A^{-1}B^{-1} and B^{-1}A^{-1}. Which one agrees with (AB)^{-1}?
Explain your finding by considering the product
(AB)(B^{-1}A^{-1})
and using associativity to regroup the products so that the middle two terms are multiplied first.

li.p:
Constructing the augmented matrix, we see that
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 4 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right],
which says that there is a unique solution \xvec = \threevec{-1}22.

Our work in part a shows that A\sim I from which we conclude that A is invertible. To find the inverse,
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right],
which says that
A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
We see that A^{-1}\threevec343 = \threevec{-1}22.
Sage tells us that B^{-1}\threevec{8}3{36} = \threevec4{-1}2.
Sage helps us see that (AB)\sim I, which tells us that AB is invertible.
We find that (AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}.

subsection.p: The next proposition summarizes much of what we have found about invertible matrices.

li.p: An n\times n matrix A is invertible if and only if A\sim I.
If A is invertible, then the solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is given by \xvec = A^{-1}\bvec.

We can find A^{-1} by finding the reduced row echelon form of \left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp I \end{array}\right]; namely,
\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp I \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{r|r} I \amp A^{-1} \end{array}\right] .
If A and B are two invertible n\times n matrices, then their product AB is also invertible and (AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}.

subsection.p:
There is a simple formula for finding the inverse of a 2\times2 matrix:
\left[\begin{array}{rr} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \\ \end{array}\right]^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad-bc} \left[\begin{array}{rr} d \amp -b \\ -c \amp a \\ \end{array}\right] , which can be easily checked. The condition that A be invertible is, in this case, reduced to the condition that ad-bc\neq 0. We will understand this condition better once we have explored determinants in . There is a similar formula for the inverse of a 3\times 3 matrix, but there is not a good reason to write it here.

subsection.title: Triangular matrices and Gaussian elimination
subsection.p:
With some of the ideas we've developed, we can recast the Gaussian elimination algorithm in terms of matrix multiplication and invertibility. This will be especially helpful later when we consider
determinants
and
LU factorizations.
Triangular matrices will play an important role.

statement.p: We say that a matrix A is lower triangular if all its entries above the diagonal are zero. Similarly, A is upper triangular if all the entries below the diagonal are zero.

subsection.p:
For example, the matrix L below is a lower triangular matrix while U is an upper triangular one.
L = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} * \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ * \amp * \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ * \amp * \amp * \amp 0 \\ * \amp * \amp * \amp * \\ \end{array}\right], \hspace{24pt} U = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} * \amp * \amp * \amp * \\ 0 \amp * \amp * \amp * \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp * \amp * \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp * \\ \end{array}\right] .

If, however, there is a zero entry on the diagonal, the matrix cannot be invertible. Considering the matrix below, we see that having a zero on the diagonal leads to a row without a pivot position.
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -3 \amp 4 \amp -4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp -4 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

statement.p: An n\times n triangular matrix is invertible if and only if the entries on the diagonal are all nonzero.
This activity explores how the row operations of scaling, interchange, and replacement can be performed using matrix multiplication.

As an example, we consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]
and apply a replacement operation that multiplies the first row by -2 and adds it to the second row. Rather than performing this operation in the usual way, we construct a new matrix by applying the desired replacement operation to the identity matrix. To illustrate, we begin with the identity matrix
I = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}
and form a new matrix by multiplying the first row by -2 and adding it to the second row to obtain
R = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Show that the product RA is the result of applying the replacement operation to A.
Explain why R is invertible and find its inverse R^{-1}.
Describe the relationship between R and R^{-1} and use the connection to replacement operations to explain why it holds.
Other row operations can be performed using a similar procedure. For instance, suppose we want to scale the second row of A by 4. Find a matrix S so that SA is the same as that obtained from the scaling operation. Why is S invertible and what is S^{-1}?
Finally, suppose we want to interchange the first and third rows of A. Find a matrix P, usually called a permutation matrix that performs this operation. What is P^{-1}?
The original matrix A is seen to be row equivalent to the upper triangular matrix U by performing three replacement operations on A:
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ \end{array}\right] = U.
Find the matrices L_1, L_2, and L_3 that perform these row replacement operations so that L_3L_2L_1 A = U.
Explain why the matrix product L_3L_2L_1 is invertible and use this fact to write A = LU. What is the matrix L that you find? Why do you think we denote it by L?

li.p:
Performing the matrix multiplication, we find that
RA = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

We know that R is invertible because it is a lower triangular matrix whose diagonal entries are all 1. We find that
R^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] , which can be verified.

But we can see this in another way as well. The replacement operation is reversible; that is, multiplying the first row by -2 and adding it to the second row can be undone by multiplying the first row by 2 and adding it to the second row.

We find that
S = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix},~~~ S^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp \frac14 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
This makes sense because scaling a row by 4 can be undone by scaling the same row by \frac14.

We find that
P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Moreover, P=P^{-1} because we can undo the interchange operation by repeating it.

Each of the matrices L_1, L_2, and L_3 is invertible so their product will be as well. Since (L_3L_2L_1)A = U, we have A = (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1}U. Moreover, L = (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1} = L_1^{-1}L_2^{-1}L_3^{-1} gives L=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]. Notice that this matrix is lower triangular so we call it L.

subsection.p:
matrix, elementary The following are examples of matrices, known as elementary matrices, that perform the row operations on a matrix having three rows.
Replacement
Multiplying the second row by 3 and adding it to the third row is performed by
L = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}. We often use L to describe these matrices because they are lower triangular.
Scaling
Multiplying the third row by 2 is performed by
S = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Interchange
Interchanging the first two rows is performed by
P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.

statement.p:
Suppose we have
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -2 \\ -3 \amp -6 \amp 3 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right].
For the forward substitution phase of Gaussian elimination, we perform a sequence of three replacement operations. The first replacement operation multiplies the first row by 3 and adds the result to the second row. We can perform this operation by multiplying A by the lower triangular matrix L_1 where
L_1A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -2 \\ -3 \amp -6 \amp 3 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 3 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp -3 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right].

The next two replacement operations are performed by the matrices
L_2 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \hspace{24pt} L_3 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]
so that L_3L_2L_1A = U = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 3 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \\ \end{bmatrix}.

Notice that the inverse of L_1 has the simple form:
L_1 = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right], \hspace{24pt} L_1^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . This says that if we want to undo the operation of multiplying the first row by 3 and adding to the second row, we should multiply the first row by -3 and add it to the second row. That is the effect of L_1^{-1}.

Notice that we now have L_3L_2L_1A = U, which gives
\begin{aligned} (L_3L_2L_1)A \amp = U \\ (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1}(L_3L_2L_1)A \amp = (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1}U \\ A \amp = (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1}U = LU\\ \end{aligned}
where L is the lower triangular matrix L = (L_3L_2L_1)^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ -3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp -2 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
This way of writing A=LU as the product of a lower and an upper triangular matrix is known as an LU factorization of A, and its usefulness will be explored in .

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
In this section, we found conditions guaranteeing that a matrix has an inverse. When these conditions hold, we also found an algorithm for finding the inverse.
A square matrix is invertible if there is a matrix B, known as the inverse of A, such that AB = I. We usually write A^{-1} = B.
The n\times n matrix A is invertible if and only if it is row equivalent to I_n, the n\times n identity matrix.
If a matrix A is invertible, we can use Gaussian elimination to find its inverse:
\left[\begin{array}{r|r} A \amp I \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{r|r} I \amp A^{-1} \end{array}\right] .
If a matrix A is invertible, then the solution to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is \xvec = A^{-1}\bvec.
The row operations of replacement, scaling, and interchange can be performed by multiplying by elementary matrices.

exercise.label: ula-proteus-3-1-reading-invertibility
exercise.title: Connecting invertibility to solutions of equations

statement.p: If A is a matrix such that A\xvec=\threevec1{-1}0 has the unique solution \xvec = \threevec102, is there anything that we can conclude about the invertibility of A? Explain your thinking.
